datasetPresenter.name: pberANKA_microarrayExpression_Waters_TimeSeries_HP-HPE_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression data for the P. berghei for four stages (Rings, Young Trophozoite, Young Schizont, Mature Schizont) using Mature Trophozoite as reference.
datasetPresenter.description:
Expression data for the P. berghei for four stages (Rings, Young Trophozoite, Young Schizont, Mature Schizont) using Mature Trophozoite as reference.

There are two datasets: HP and HPE. HP is High Producer (as in gametocytes) and HPE is High Producer "E". HP was mechanically passaged on a weekly basis from mouse to mouse and 10 independent experiments were set up (HPA-HPJ). The parasites were observed, waiting for non-producing parasites to appear. HPE was the chosen one. A deletion in HP was assumed to have created HPE (they are otherwise isogenic) and KO'd the production of gametocytes. In such a scenario the non-producer would quickly overgrow the producer. Both are cloned.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_genomeFeature_Llinas_TransFactorBindingSites_GFF2_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: P. falciparum Trans-factor binding sites from Manuel Llinas
datasetPresenter.displayCategory: Genomes and Annotation: TF Binding Sites
datasetPresenter.summary: P. falciparum Trans-factor binding sites from Manuel Llinas
datasetPresenter.description:
The DNA sequence motifs bound by each ApiAP2 transcription factor were derived from protein binding microarray data using P. falciparum AP2 domains. Protein binding microarrays are non-organism specific and contain matches to all contiguous 10-mers at least once and non-palindromic 8-mers up to 32 times. The DNA motifs were determined using purified recombinant AP2 domains and the resulting position weight matrix for each AP2 domain was used to search upstream regions for significant matches. The AP2 domain that binds to each motif is indicated at the end of the gene ID. Binding sites are based on sequence matches only and have not been verified in vivo.
For further information, contact Manuel Llinás: manuel@princeton.edu

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: P. falciparum (3D7) chromosomes sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
A high quality draft genome of Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 was produced by an international consortium in 2002 (Gardner et al., Nature 2002; 419:498-511). However, the completed genome, with no gaps, is being finished at the Sanger Institute. The latest version (v3.0) comprises systematically corrected and reassembled sequence, plus genome-wide re-annotation, incorporating annotations from a community annotation workshop, ongoing community feedback and detailed manual inspection by curation staff at the Sanger Institute. A manuscript describing the latest version is in preparation. We therefore request that you consult with the Principle Investigators before undertaking large scale analyses of the annotation or underlying sequence.
Contact webmaster@genedb.org for further details.

Previous to PlasmoDB release 9.0, the source of the sequence and annotation was the following:
Chromosome 1, 3-9 and 13 were sequenced at the Sanger Institute.
Chromosome 2, 10, 11 and 14 were sequenced at The Institute for Genomic Research and the Naval Medical Research Center.
Chromosome 12 was sequenced at the Stanford Genome Technology Center.

link.text: Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 on GeneDB

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayPlatform_A-MEXP-75-MTC_KI_Plasmodium_falciparum_33k_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Karolinska Institutet MTC P. falciparum Oligo Array
datasetPresenter.summary: Karolinska Institutet MTC P. falciparum Oligo Array
datasetPresenter.description: ArrayExpress (A-MEXP-75). The 70-mer oligonucleotides microarray consisted of 6850 probes. From there, 6542 probes (Malaria Genome Oligo Set Version 1.0) were designed and synthesized by Qiagen Operon and 14 probes were obtained from the SpotReport Alien oligo array validation system (Stratagene, CA, USA). The rest of the oligos were selected using ArrayDesigner Version 1 (Premier Biosoft International, CA, USA). Oligonucleotides were dissolved in 1:3 of DMSO:dH2O at a final concentration of 40 microM in preparation for spotting on CMT-UltraGaps slides. Microarraying was done by Genetix Qarray. Each probe was printed in quadruplicate on the slides.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Su_seven_stages_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Gene expression in seven stages of (sexual and asexual) of Plasmodium falciparum
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA-Seq coverage from P. falciparum seven stages (ring, early and late troph, schizont, gametocyte II and V, and ookenete) study from the laboratory of Xin-zhuan Su.
datasetPresenter.description:
Paper abstract:
Plasmodium falciparum genome contain errors. Although there have been efforts to obtain complete cDNA sequences to correct the errors, the coverage of cDNA sequences on the predicted genes is still incomplete, and many gene models for those expressed in sexual or mosquito stages have not been validated. Antisense transcripts have widely been reported in P. falciparum; however, the extent and pattern of antisense transcripts in different developmental stages remain largely unknown.

Results:
We have sequenced seven bidirectional libraries from ring, early and late trophozoite, schizont, gametocyte II, gametocyte V, and ookinete, and four strand-specific libraries from late trophozoite, schizont, gametocyte II, and gametocyte V of the 3D7 parasites. Alignment of the cDNA sequences to the 3D7 reference genome revealed stage-specific antisense transcripts and novel intron-exon splicing junctions. Sequencing of strand-specific cDNA libraries suggested that more genes are expressed in one direction in gametocyte than in schizont. Alternatively spliced genes, antisense transcripts, and stage-specific expressed genes were also characterized.

Conclusions:
It is necessary to continue to sequence cDNA from different developmental stages, particularly those of non-erythrocytic stages. The presence of antisense transcripts in some gametocyte and ookinete genes suggests that these antisense RNA may play an important role in gene expression regulation and parasite development. Future gene expression studies should make use of directional cDNA libraries. Antisense transcripts may partly explain the observed discrepancy between levels of mRNA and protein expression. 

Samples:
1.	Schizont (Sc)
2.	Ring (R)
3.	early trophozoite (ET)
4.	late trophozoite (LT)
5.	ookinete (Oo; 3D7 ookinetes transcripts obtained from the midgut of A. gambiae (L3-5 strain) female mosquitoes)
6.	gametocytes II (GII; day 8)
7.	gametocytes V  (GV; day 15)

datasetPresenter.name: pvivSaI1_microarrayExpression_Westenberger_array_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Westenberger Pvivax ExpressionData
datasetPresenter.description:
Sporozoites were purified from dissected mosquitoes fed on monkeys infected with the genome reference strain Salvador I at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, Georgia. Asexual blood stage parasites were obtained from P. vivax-infected patients in Iquitos, Peru. White blood cells were removed by CF-11 cellulose column filtration, asexual parasites were enriched by gradient centrifugation and purified by saponin lysis of RBCs. Total RNA was isolated from purified parasites and subjected to two rounds of RNA amplification for microarray analysis as described previously (Zhou, et al. 2008). Experimental technical replicate hybridizations were performed for the single sporozoite sample and two asexual samples (CM012 and CM013). Gene expression values were calculated using MOID; expression profiles were clustered using OPI as described previously (Zhou, et al. 2008).

Scott J Westenberger, Colleen M McClean, Rana Chattopadhyay, Neekesh V Dharia, Jane M Carlton, John W Barnwell, William E Collins, Stephen L Hoffman, Yingyao Zhou, Joseph M Vinetz, Elizabeth A Winzeler. Plasmodium vivax transcriptome analysis reveals divergent in vivo blood stage profiles and species-specific sporozoite gene expression. (in submission)

datasetPresenter.name: pfalIT_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The genome of Plasmodium falciparum IT was produced by the Parasite Genomics Group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with funding from the EVIMalaR Consortium (a European Commission Funded Network of Excellence).
datasetPresenter.description:
The genome of Plasmodium falciparum IT was produced by the Parasite Genomics Group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with funding from the EVIMalaR Consortium (a European Commission Funded Network of Excellence).
This draft version of the genome was generated by iterative mapping reads of P. falciparum IT against the P. falciparum 3D7 genome. Subtelomeric genes have been transferred from P. falciparum 3D7 based on location. The Parasite Genomics Group plans on publishing the completed and annotated sequence in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible.
Permission of the principal investigator (Matthew Berriman, mb4@sanger.ac.uk) should be obtained before publishing chromosome- or genome- scale analyses of the sequences or annotations.
Please contact Thomas Otto (tdo@sanger.ac.uk) for further details.

link.text: Plasmodium falciparum - Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute

datasetPresenter.name: pyoeyoeliiYM_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description:
The assembly of P. yoelii yoelii YM was made using short-fragment Illumina reads and scaffolded with 454 paired-reads from a 3kb library. The assembly was computationally improved using PAGIT and annotated by transfer from the P. berghei ANKA reference. Genes in subtelomeric regions were predicted ab initio. The annotation has been manually re-inspected genome-wide. This work was funded by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute and the European Union's 7th Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013) under grant agreement no242095. The DNA was provided by Tony Holder and Solabomi Ogun (Division of Parasitology, MRC National Institute for Medical Research, Mill Hill, London).

Permission of the principal investigator (Matthew Berriman, mb4@sanger.ac.uk) should be obtained before publishing chromosome- or genome- scale analyses of the sequences or annotations.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayExpression_E-MEXP-128_IsogenicClonesStages_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: 3D7AH1S2 vs. 3D7S8.4 (ring, trophozite and schizont) - meta data
datasetPresenter.summary: Antigenic variation is a survival mechanism developed by the malaria parasite P. falciparum in order to allow for the establishment of a chronic infection. Here we have studied clonal differences in the transcriptomes of two isogenic P. falciparum clones (3D7S8.4 and 3D7AH1S2) of distinct adhesive and antigenic phenotypes employing a P. falciparum 70-mer oligonucleotide microarray. Fifteen transcripts were highly differentially expressed (greater than a 5-fold change) with five transcripts upregulated in 3D7AH1S2 compared to 3D7S8.4, and ten downregulated. Identified genes encode apical organellar (Gbph2, GBP-related antigen), cell cycle and DNA/RNA processing (SERA-5, RNA-methylase), cell-rescue, defense/virulence (RESA-2, RIFIN, PfEMP1) and hypothetical proteins (PFB0115w, PFI1445w, MAL13P1.121). A number of short and full-length var transcripts were differentially expressed between the clones but one full-length transcript was dominant in both rings and trophozoites (PFD0630c versus PFF0845c). Distinct members of two other variant gene families (phist-a and rif-like), scattered over the subtelomeric areas of the 14 chromosomes, were also found to be clonally and developmentally expressed. Three sibling-clones of 3D7AH1S2 (3D7AH1S1, -S3, -S4) were further studied for the expression of transcripts upregulated in 3D7AH1S2 compared to 3D7S8.4. Individual var and phist-a genes were found expressed in all of the clones while the expression of a rif-like gene and gbph2 varied in-between the clones. The present data provides evidence for complex transcriptional differences between closely related isogenic P. falciparum of distinct adhesive and antigenic characteristics.

A number of short and full-length var transcripts were differentially expressed between the clones but one full-length transcript was dominant in both rings and trophozoites (PFD0630c versus PFF0845c). datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_massSpec_Lasonder_Mosquito_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: P. falciparum: Profile of Sporozoite Maturation (NF54) (Lasonder et al.)
datasetPresenter.summary: Salivary gland sporozoites were collected from mosquito (Anopheles stephensi, Sind-Kasur, 3-5 days old) salivary glands 18-22 days after infection with P. falciparum NF54 gametocytes. Oocysts and oocyst-derived sporozoits were collected from mosquito midguts at 7-8 and 13-14 days after infection, respectively. Complex protein mixtures from each sample were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.
datasetPresenter.description: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts and salivary gland sporozoites by Edwin Lasonder lab. Oocyst (OOC): 1-2 x 10^4 OOCs were collected from midguts of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 7-8 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Oocyst-derived sporozoites (ODS): 1.4-3.8 x10^7 ODSs were collected from midguts of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 13-14 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Salivary gland sporozoites (SGS): 1.3-2.5 x10^7 SGSs were collected from salivary glands of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 18-22 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Please note that since samples were contaminated with host (mosquito) proteins, they were measured up to four times with exclusion lists to acquire MS/MS spectra of P. falciparum peptides. Sequenced peptides were excluded for sequencing in subsequent runs, resulting in an enrichment of low abundant peptides in LC-MS/MS runs.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_chipChipExper_Winzeler_Westenberger_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: A high-density oligonucleotide microarray to map the position and enrichment of nucleosomes across the entire genome of P. falciparum (3D7) at three time points of the intra-erythrocytic developmental cycle using an unmodified histone H4 antibody for chromatin immunoprecipitation of nucleosome-bound DNA.
datasetPresenter.description: A high-density oligonucleotide microarray to map the position and enrichment of nucleosomes across the entire genome of P. falciparum (3D7) at three time points of the intra-erythrocytic developmental cycle using an unmodified histone H4 antibody for chromatin immunoprecipitation of nucleosome-bound DNA. Additionally, trophozoites were assessed with histone H3K9 acetylation (H3K9ac) antibodies. Parasites were synchronized twice with 5% sorbitol. Rings = 12 hrs; Trophozoites = 30 hrs; Schizont = 42 hrs. Raw data available in geo.

datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiles of transcriptional variation between Plasmodium falciparum strains (Cortes).
datasetPresenter.description: To characterize transcriptional variation in P. falciparum, and to identify genes under clonally variant gene expression, the transcriptome of 21 P. falciparum lines was characterized. The analysis on was based four independent comparisons, with all parasite lines within a comparison sharing a clonal origin. We also performed a fifth comparison including genetically-different parasite lines. Furthermore, comparative genome hybridization (CGH) was performed for all 21 parasite lines.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_massSpec_Lasonder_Blood_Stages_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: P. falciparum: Gametocytogenesis: trophozoites vs early or late gametocytes (3D7 / NF54) (Silvestrini et al.)
datasetPresenter.summary: Gametocyte-free trophozoites of P. falciparum were obtained from clone F12, a 3D7A derivative which fails to produce the early gametocyte stages. Early developing gametocytes (Early stage I-II gametocytes) were obtained using a three-step purification process of transgenic 3D7A parasites expressing a Pfg27-GFP fusion protein (expressed early in sexual differentiation). Mature gametocytes (Late stage V gametocytes) were obtained by Percoll purification of mature gametocyte cultures previously treated with N-acetylglucosamine to clear residual asexual parasites. Protein preparations from each parasite stage were anlyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayExpression_Cowman_InvasionKOs_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Molecular mechanism for switching of P. falciparum invasion pathways into human erythrocytes.
datasetPresenter.description: The malaria parasite, P. falciparum, exploits multiple ligand-receptor interactions, called invasion pathways, to invade the host erythrocyte. Strains of P. falciparum vary in their dependency on sialated red cell receptors for invasion. We show that switching from sialic acid-dependent to independent invasion is reversible and depends on parasite ligand utilisation. Expression of P. falciparum reticulocyte-binding like homologue 4 (PfRh4) correlates with sialic acid-independent invasion and PfRh4 is essential for switching invasion pathways. Differential activation of PfRh4 represents a novel mechanism of invasion pathway control and provides P.falciparum with exquisite adaptability in the face of erythrocyte receptor polymorphisms and host immune responses. (taken from GEO record GSE2878).

datasetPresenter.summary: E-GEOD-10022 array data(Su lab)
datasetPresenter.description:
E-GEOD-10022 array data(Su lab)
In this study three isogenic lines of P. falciparum (106/1K76, 106/176I, and 106/76I-352K) were compared to each other with or without CQ treatment (3-hours, 3 biological replicas). The Affymetrix Gene Chip was used to generate gene expression profiles. For this study the parental line is 106/1K76.

datasetPresenter.name: pyoe17XNL_dbxref_simple_gene2RMgmPhenotypeUrl_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Phenotypes from Genetically Modified Rodent Malaria Parasite database
datasetPresenter.summary: Phenotype links from Genetically Modified Rodent Malaria Parasites: Pberghei.eu.
datasetPresenter.description: Phenotype links from Genetically Modified Rodent Malaria Parasites: Pberghei.eu hosts a database containing information on genetically modified rodent malaria parasite lines generated by many labs worldwide. Specifically, it contains data of three rodent malaria parasite species; Plasmodium berghei, P. yoelii and P. chabaudi. The aim of this database is to provide the research community access to detailed information on the generation (e.g. disruption, tagging, mutation, transgene expression) and phenotype of genetically modified malaria parasites. The database not only provides information on 'successful' mutants with a clear phenotype, but also (un)published mutants without a clear phenotype and (un)published negative trials to disrupt genes.
